author: cbc
title: Storm shuts down most of Nova Scotia for 2nd day
text:
The strong winds and steady snow from Monday's massive blizzard continue today, prompting widespread cancellations across Nova Scotia.
Schools across the province remain closed. Malls and many businesses are either closed or have delayed opening until noon.
Check CBC Storm Centre for latest closures and travel details The TransCanada highway between Amherst and the New Brunswick border was closed, reopening at 5:30 a.m. Travellers are advised to check before venturing out today.
At least one creature isn't too perturbed by the storm that's been gripping the province for the past two days. (Nic Meloney/CBC)
Snow this morning will taper to flurries ending this morning in the Halifax area, says Environment Canada. But blowing snow conditions will continue into this afternoon with winds gusting to 50 kilometres per hour. Temperatures will remain steady near -4 C.
Blizzard persists in northern areas, Cape Breton It's mainly cloudy along the southwest with blowing snow in exposed areas, winds gusting up to 70 kilometres will diminish early this afternoon. Temperatures will stay at about -4 C.
Blizzard warnings remain in effect in Cumberland County and the Cobequid Pass as the storm continues to track east. Wind speeds of up to 80 kilometres will result in frequent whiteout conditions. Temperatures will be about -6 C.
Cape Breton will also be in the grip of the blizzard until this afternoon as snow, at times heavy, turns to flurries this afternoon with temperatures steady at -4 C.
Both regions will get another 10-15 centimetres before the storm moves out.
No Halifax Transit bus service until 5 p.m.
Metro Transit in Halifax has announced it won't return buses to the road until 5 p.m. on Tuesday. Ferry service is set to resume at 7 a.m.
About 5,300 Nova Scotia Power customers had no electricity Tuesday morning, with the majority of outages — 2,679 — in Bridgewater.
Blizzard shuts down most of Nova Scotia as Halifax schools cancelled for Tuesday The power company said it restored power to more than 48,000 customers overnight, working in extreme weather conditions with poor visibility and road conditions.
"We are estimating power restoration of the majority of our customers by the end of day Tuesday," spokesman Steve Pothier said Tuesday morning.
Marine Atlantic crossings between Nova Scotia and Newfoundland are delayed until 11:45 p.m.
Flights at Halifax Stanfield International Airport are either cancelled or delayed until mid-morning.
